content.intro:
Bordered on the east by the Tyrrhenian Sea and to the west by the Mediterranean, northern Corsica is an unspoilt paradise of traditional crafts and exceptional sites.

The wild beauty of this peninsula, home to small idyllic coves and crystal-clear waters, is a must for nature lovers. Take the spectacular coastal road marked by the scents of immortelle flowers and myrtle to admire the towering rock formations shaped by the sea. Enter inland for a hike or go horseback riding in the bush and stop to refresh in the shade of olive trees. Venture out in a boat to the Scandola Nature Reserve, concealing mysterious caves over which osprey hover. Explore the amazing black beach of the village of Nonza or visit the Agriates Desert. In Balagne, explore the narrow streets of the fortified town of Calvi, supposed legendary birthplace of Christopher Columbus, before visiting the charming villages of Lumio, L'Ile Rousse, and Saint Florent. At the tip of Cap Corse, in the village of Centuri, you can crack open a lobster and try to make out what you see of the Italian coast on a clear day. For a city break, let yourself be charmed by the colourful streets of Bastia, replete with designer, luxury, and fashion boutiques, as well as concept stores that attract people from around the island. Northern Corsica is worth a visit at any time of year. Throughout the seasons, events such as the Italian Film Festival of Bastia, the Lama Film Festival, Porto Latino Music Festival in Saint-Florent, the 'Cap Sur le Rire Festival' (Comedy Festival) in Brando, and the renowned Calvi on the Rocks electronic and rock music festival, punctuate the island's cultural life. Discover, as well, the region's rich religious heritage by visiting chapels and churches in villages and attending traditional processions. Northern Corsica is an ideal destination to visit as a couple for a relaxing weekend, in family for a few days of sports expedition in the midst of nature, or between friends to simply enjoy a week, fully immersed in the island's life.

content.title: Hôtel Calavita: zen, eco-friendly breaks

introduction.small: A fantastic base for exploring the picture-perfect beaches and villages of the Cap Corse, this hotel is taking a sustainable, eco-friendly approach to holidays.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Hôtel Calavita: zen, eco-friendly breaks

paragraphs.text:
Anyone born in the area around Bastia knows the outline of this simple, elegant building at the top of Route du Cap Corse, where it stands looking out over the Mediterranean. For almost 50 years, the hotel – formerly Hôtel Thalassa – has been a favourite meeting place for the young people of Bastia: somewhere to catch up and have fun. Then, three friends decided to restore the place to its former glory. Restored, enhanced, and now home to a pool, open-air jacuzzi and rooftop bar with breath-taking views of the Tyrrhenian Sea, it has been renamed the Calavita after the stunning cove it overlooks.

Bringing guests all the comfort of a modern hotel with its 32 fully-equipped rooms, lounge, bar and restaurant, the Thalassa's heart and soul can still be felt today at the Calavita, as can its foundations in sincere Corsican hospitality. It is committed to minimising its environmental impact, as well as its water and energy use. A certified ‘Rispettu' hotel – Corsica's sustainable hospitality label – it makes a conscious effort to be as green as possible, for example by reducing the amount of waste it produces and offering homemade “eco-designed” Corsican lunches featuring organic produce sourced from local suppliers.

Hôtel Calavita
39 route du Cap
20200 Bastia

+33 (0)4 95 31 56 63

Rooms: 65 EUR

https://www.hotelcalavita.com/en/

content.title: Le Mademoiselle, relaxing lounge ambiance

introduction.small: Discover all the savours and subtlety of Mediterranean cuisine, featuring ingredients from land and sea that will delight even the most discerning diners.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Le Mademoiselle, relaxing lounge ambiance

paragraphs.text:
Just up from Bastia's Vieux Port and not far from the Église Saint-Jean-Baptiste, Le Mademoiselle has won the hearts of everyone in Bastia in the space of just a few short years. Depending on your mood – and the weather! – you can head out of the Mediterranean heat into the welcoming, shady stone arches of the 200sqm dining room, or escape to the peace and quiet of vast patio, away from the vibrancy of Bastia's Terra Vecchia neighbourhood.

Once you have made this difficult choice, yet more await: although the pizzas alone are well worth a visit here, the tuna mi-cuit with mixed baby vegetables and wild rice timbale is also sure to pique your curiosity. Then – we hate to tell you – once you have eyed your neighbour's table, you'll also be torn between the confit lamb shanks with mashed potato, and the vegetable linguine in a truffle cream sauce… Fans of comfort food, meanwhile, will be sorely tempted by the braised octopus, which regulars will tell you is the best around. Then a sip of brama – a typical Corsican white wine – is all it takes for you to suddenly feel your very soul come alive with true, Corsican passion.

Le Mademoiselle
4 place Fontaine Neuve
20200 Bastia

+33 (0)6 27 33 34 43

https://www.facebook.com/lemademoisellebastia

Menu: around 27 EUR

content.title: Chez Vincent, Mediterranean creativity in the heart of the citadel

introduction.small: With its unique panoramic view of the old town and inventive gastronomic offer, Chez Vincent ticks all the right boxes of a great restaurant

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Chez Vincent, Mediterranean creativity in the heart of the citadel

paragraphs.text:
At the foot of the citadel that towers over Bastia, the terrace of Chez Vincent restaurant is regularly crowded. Why you may ask? First, it enjoys unique views of the old town and the port, the blue horizon always in the background. A truly postcard-worthy landscape for lunch! Then, Ludovic Rodaro's cooking follows the same course as his father Vincent: your dish will absolutely rival the gorgeous panorama under your eyes. Considering the creative gastronomic offer on display, which depend on market supplies, the endeavour is a success, and Chez Vincent is now a must-go-to among all gourmet lovers.

Take your pick among the homemade duck-stuffed ravioli with butternut, nuts, parmesan cream and girolle mushrooms, a large selection of pizzas (from the classic ones to original creations like truffle cream, gorgonzola, candied apples and nuts), as well as the panzetta pork pie house special. Remember to book in advance if you wish to pair an exceptional meal with unique landscapes, for the time of a meal you will not forget.

Chez Vincent
12 rue Saint-Michel
20200 Bastia

+33 (0)4 95 31 62 50

https://www.facebook.com/chez.vincent.1/

Menu: around 25 EUR

content.title: Highly refined gastronomy at the Domaine de La Signoria

introduction.small: In the land of the goat and the lobster, talented chef Alexandre Fabris offers you a gustatory journey that reveals all the flavours of Mediterranean cuisine.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Highly refined gastronomy at the Domaine de La Signoria

paragraphs.text:
On the outskirts of Calvi, overlooking the Bonifato Valley, this old Genoese estate, entirely renovated by Jean-Baptiste Ceccaldi now houses the luxurious and popular La Signoria resort. This charming address welcomes its guests in a discreet and elegant atmosphere.

In the shade of the starred restaurant's large cream-coloured parasols, the tables on the terrace face the majestic mountainous landscape. And in the pastel tones of the ochre and beige indoor dining room lies a huge fireplace. Everything is set for you to enjoy the infinitely refined dishes of chef Alexandre Fabris: swordfish pastilla in cardamom, cuttlefish ink sauce linguini with squids, or the venison filet marinated in Corsican wine then roasted, served with bayberry sauce… The sommelier will help you pair your meal with the best Corsican wines stored in the cellar. End on a sweet note with figs from the maquis, roasted in olive oil and served with a light Madagascar vanilla cream.

The establishment is closed seasonally, from November to March.

La Palmeraie de La Signoria
Route de la forêt de Bonifato
20260 Calvi
+33 (0)4 95 65 93 00
https://www.hotel-la-signoria.com/en/calvi-restaurant.html

content.title: Ghisoni's Coffee House, between the pear and… the coffee

introduction.small: With Ghisoni's Coffee House, Bastia offers a hybrid place where you can stop at any hour, whatever your hunger level or desire.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Ghisoni's Coffee House, between the pear and… the coffee

paragraphs.text:
Located at the beginning of Rue César Campinchi, halfway between the Port of Bastia and its train station, Ghisoni's Coffee House welcomes you to a completely open setting, at once tea room, restaurant and fine food store. The old setting with exposed beams and stone walls has been preserved and adapted to modern comfort, highlighted by sober and elegant decor with plush armchairs, wooden furniture and ceiling filament bulbs.
The pastries are the house specialty, the generosity of their portions matching their beautiful appearance, while the original hot drinks will satisfy the most demanding coffee, tea and chocolate aficionados. You can also have lunch or dinner on site, the restaurant menu offering homemade burgers, pizza by the slice and various sandwiches. Reservations are recommended all day long, as regulars are rushing there.

content.title: Liberata Hotel, a historical heritage

introduction.small: Liberata hotel brings together elegance, luxury and well-being in L'Île Rousse, in one of the most typical Corsican regions.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Liberata Hotel, a historical heritage

paragraphs.text:
In a stately art nouveau style home, at the very heart of L'Île Rousse - an hour and a half drive from Bastia - a hotel filled with character, the Liberata, awaits you. Its prime location by the sea ensures tranquillity and privacy for a peaceful getaway.
The timeless decor emphasizes the elegance of noble materials and the comfort of the furniture, all in a manner house style. Thanks to their furnished balcony or terrace, the 22 bright and spacious rooms all offer unsurpassed views of the Mediterranean. You can enjoy an intimate breakfast with the transparent water of the open sea, for a gentle morning awakening.
While the walls are light coloured to preserve the coolness and protect you from the scorching Corsican climate, the furniture brings a subtle colourful note, like the stylish chairs, bedspread and floral cushions. To perfect the image of a real little cocoon is a handmade carpet throne in the middle of your room. A piece of Corsican paradise that is hard to forget!

Liberata Hotel

content.title: Back to the past at the archaeological site of Aléria

introduction.small: The archaeological site of Aléria and the accompanying museum deserve a couple hours of your time.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Back to the past at the archaeological site of Aléria

paragraphs.text:
On the East Coast of Corsica, definitely make your way to Aléria. This treasure was discovered in 1840 by Prosper Mérimée, the inspector general of historical monuments of the time, but it was in the 20th century that proper archaeological digs took place on the ruins of this ancient Roman city, capital of the island in Antiquity.

In the early 1960s, some 200 tombs were discovered in a pre-Roman necropolis, located a bit south of the site. You can admire them at the Jérôme Carcopino Archaeological Museum located within the Fort of Matra, a 16th-century fortress where you will also find other objects unearthed at Aléria such as busts, silver sculptures and pottery. The museum and visit of the grounds will give you a glimpse into daily life at the time.

Aléria Archaeological site
Le Fort

+33 (0)4 95 46 10 92

https://www.isula.corsica/patrimoine/Le-site-archeologique-d-Aleria_a10.html

content.title: On the wine route to Patrimonio

introduction.small: Opt for a road trip to discover the vineyards of Patrimonio.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: On the wine route to Patrimonio

paragraphs.text:
The Patrimonio valley rolls out wine treasures and vineyards, internationally renowned for their excellence, in the heart of sumptuous Corsican landscapes. Here, the wines have been set apart by their appellation d'origine contrôlée (AOC) for over 40 years and are considered the best on the Island of Beauty. Try the reds with subtle notes of berries, the dry whites or one of the famous Corsican rosés, in moderation of course. The wines of Patrimonio are primarily made of the nielluccio, vermentino and muscat grape varieties.

This mythical wine route allows you to cross about 30 estates. You can create your own tour, suiting your every mood and desire, but rest assured you will easily find your way as signposts mark the way. Over 500 hectares of land, you will pass by Saint-Florent and Farinole, whose cellars you can discover on a guided tour. With a glass of wine and a plate of Corsican charcuterie, your holiday can finally begin!

 

Tourism Office
Parking Saint-Nicolas
20200 Bastia

+33 (0)4 95 54 20 40

https://www.bastia-tourisme.com/en/bastia-and-the-wine-route/

content.title: Corte, the perched village of Corsica

introduction.small: Sitting on a rocky outcrop where it proudly overlooks Corsica's Regional Natural Park, the little village of Corte is worth the detour.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Corte, the perched village of Corsica

paragraphs.text:
The historical and cultural capital of Corsica, Corte, 70 km from Bastia, offers an exceptional view of the Restonica and Tavignano valleys from its perch. The best place to look out over the old city is from the top of the "eagle's nest" in this citadel built in the 15th century, now home to the regional Anthropology Museum.

After visiting the museum, which covers traditional Corsica, and the multiple upheavals that shaped the island, you can stroll among the cobbled streets of Corte, looking about its schist houses and climbing its rather steep staircases. A typical landscape is visible to you - behold the idyllic landscape with its lush flora. The village is the starting point of excursions to the Corsican Regional Natural Park: get ready for white water kayaking for the more athletic, or swimming and hiking for those who desire more tranquillity. There is something for everyone.

Corte Tourism Office
La Citadelle
20250 Corte

+33 (0)4 95 46 26 70

www.corte-tourisme.com/la-citadelle-corse-41-fr.html

content.title: A getaway in the Agriates' wilderness

introduction.small: Halfway between Saint Florent and the Île Rousse, the Corsican coast borders wilderness of green scrubland. Discover the Agriates desert.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: A getaway in the Agriates' wilderness

paragraphs.text:
Stunning, unexpected, incredible! Centuries of transhumance and cultivation have shaped this vast expanse of rough and arid land, elegantly lined by the most beautiful beaches of Corsica. The hiking and equestrian trails trace across green valleys, and the cream-coloured sand embraces the crests and granites carved by sea spray.
Protected by the Conservatoire du littoral (coastline preservation), the Agriates are now seen as a place of escape, a Mediterranean paradise for both locals and tourists, all eager to lose themselves at the foot of high snowy summits. Put on your best hiking shoes to tread upon hidden paths through one of the only deserts in Western Europe and soak up the spectacle that is offered to you: the untamed shores of the northern coastline reach as far as the eye can see. Put on your bathing suit! The clear water of the beaches of La Roya, Saleccia, Ostriconi or Ghignu froth up under your feet and invite you to take a dive. This is what heaven must look like…

Désert des Agriates
20246 Santo-Pietro-di-Tenda

http://www.corsica-saintflorent.com/Les_Agriate_page_145_1,266.htm

content.title: Scimia Calvese, where Icarus' heart is set alight

introduction.small: Among Calvi's large tall pine trees, small and enthusiastic figures walk in the sky and throw themselves in thin air. Welcome to the A Scimia Calvese path!

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Scimia Calvese, where Icarus' heart is set alight

paragraphs.text:
Founded in 1993 by Olivier and Stéphane Leonetti, the Altore school is specialized in teaching and supervising outdoor sports. It is near Calvi's beach that a treetop adventure course spreads around the pine forest. A Scimia Calvese consists in dozens of workshops and zip-lines to allow you to explore the landscape without ever setting foot on dry land.

Equipped and trained by professionals, you may be tempted by the most adventurous trails, usually used by the most daring athletes. From introduction to complete autonomy, Calvi's aerial strolls bring families and friends together for a truly enjoyable moment, lulled by the lapping of the Mediterranean. The secured course will strip you out of your fears as you set forth over 100m high in the air. Warm winds blow through your hair as the Balagne region welcomes you with rolling open arms.

A Scimia Calvese
Calvi's pine forest (casino entrance)
20260 Calvi

+33 (0)6 83 39 69 06

https://en.altore.com//parcours-aventure

content.title: Cap Corse: extraordinary landscapes that will take your breath away

introduction.small: At the far north of the island, the picturesque Cap Corse peninsula stretches 40 kilometres long and 15 kilometres wide, offering magnificent views framed by turquoise sea.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Cap Corse: extraordinary landscapes that will take your breath away

paragraphs.text:
Dubbed by the Corsicans 'Isula di isula' – the 'island of the island' – the Cap Corse is considered one of the most spectacular parts of Corsica.

Visit typical villages with infinite charms, natural, unspoiled beaches, intimate bays and quaint fishing ports, or climb leisurely into the hills towards small towns to enjoy spectacular views: from the very tip of the Cape, you will even be able to make out Italy. On the east coast, meanwhile, you can bask in one of its gorgeous sandy coves.

From Bastia to St Florent, not to mention the lesser-known villages of Centuri, Nonza, and Erbalunga, its many romantic walks and sunbathing spots on beautiful coastal beaches make the Cap Corse difficult to resist, be it for a long stay or short, sunny getaway.

https://www.bastia-tourisme.com/en/

content.title: Clos Antonini, a refreshing break

introduction.small: Near the top of the mountain, in the heart of Sant'Antonino, a 9th-century village of cobbled streets lined with quaintly restored houses, Clos Antonini invites you to savour the delicate tartness of citrus.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Clos Antonini, a refreshing break

paragraphs.text:
Every time one goes through Sant'Antonino, one should stop at Clos Antonini to drink, on site or to take away, a refreshing lemon juice or grape juice. Located at the entrance of the village, among the food stalls of lemons and olive oil, wine, citrus, and fresh fig jams may also be bought.

With limited access for motorized vehicles, walk up the steep streets of the village built in the 9th century; if you want to make your visit more comfortable and original, take the 'donkey' taxi service. You will find taverns and cafés on the village square to restore you while you admire the verdant panorama.

Listed among the most beautiful villages in Corsica, it is located along the D151 road, which will easily take you to other atypical towns like Corbara and Murato.

Clos Antonini
Place de l'Église
20220 Sant'Antonino

+33 (0)4 95 61 76 83

www.gustidicorsica.com/en/9-356/producteur/antonini.html

content.title: A Matricula, the honeyed side of Balagna

introduction.small: Beekeepers from father to son, Jean-Claude and Francois Gras operate more than 200 hives located in the municipality of Santa-Reparata-di-Balagna.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: A Matricula, the honeyed side of Balagna

paragraphs.text:
Carrying on the tradition of harvesting honey products, A Matricula guarantees quality honey, with rich flavours and subtle aromas, combining the sweetness of spring flowers and the strong character of chestnuts.

There are six varieties of honey and related products, all stamped with the “Mele-di-Corsica” protected designation of origin. There are tastings at the shop, offering honey, spice bread, biscuits with honey, and hazelnuts from Cervione.

The beekeepers will share anecdotes to explain the concept of 'transhumance', which involves moving their hives to southern Corsica and the chestnut forests on mountain heights when spring ends so as to respect the rhythm of the seasons and the blossom cycle that bees love.

A Matricula

content.title: Case Latine, poised between sea and mountain

introduction.small: Perched atop the village of Lama, in symbiosis with the surrounding flora and fauna, Case Latine is an exceptional refuge.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Case Latine, poised between sea and mountain

paragraphs.text:
With views opening onto the valley, the delta and Ostriconi Beach, this residence of charm and character offers eight spacious yet cosy and intimate apartments in tints of beige, ivory, and light grey, with terracotta or wood floors and slate bathrooms.

You can quench your thirst at the bar while admiring the medieval houses, Tuscan palace, and the gazebo from the terrace. If you want to dine, the Campu Latinu offers snacks for lunch and serves gourmet cuisine using regional produce for dinner. To complete this divine setting, there are beautiful pools dug into the rock, which offer the sensation of river swimming.

Not far away, you can visit the village of Pietralba, located in the Canale microregion. You may also admire the Saint-Roch and Santa Maria Assunta churches, as well as the Saint-Michael and A Nunziata chapels.

Open from late March to mid-November.

content.title: A Piattatella, a unique place in the heart of the maquis

introduction.small: In perfect harmony with nature, A Piattatella whose name means ‘the hiding place' is for all aesthetes looking for a change of scene.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: A Piattatella, a unique place in the heart of the maquis

paragraphs.text:
The hotel has 17 rooms opening on to the Reginu Valley in an authentic and luxurious setting.

To perfect its ties with nature, the cosy hotel restaurant offers intuitive cuisine with products from the kitchen garden.

And for a healthy mind in a healthy body A Piattatella leaves you free access to a heated infinity pool in the shade of olive trees, a fitness area equipped with six machines, an outdoor health trail, a panoramic spa nestled on a rocky outcrop comprising an organic sauna, an aromatic steam bath, a massage chair, and a tea room.

Perched 218 metres high on a promontory, the "gold islands" in the heart of the Monticello village show their ancient origins. For instance, the San Sebastianu Church was built in the early 17th-century. A web of narrow streets and vaulted passageways under some colourful houses mark out their limits.

Open from late March to mid-November.

content.title: Castel Brando, the majesty of the Cap Corse

introduction.small: Discover this majestic residence built in 1853 by a Corsican doctor of the Napoleonic armies in the picturesque village of Erbalunga.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Castel Brando, the majesty of the Cap Corse

paragraphs.text:
Family house beautifully restored into an opulent and refined place by owners Joëlle and Jean-Paul Pieri, Castel Brando is a must-go-to in the region.

The hotel has a range of rooms and a suite with pared-down decor, and offers regional gourmet products to tickle your taste buds, as well as a fine list of Corsica's best wines, all of which may be found in the hotel shop.

A concierge is at your service to make restaurant reservations and organise tourism activities, and if you want to relax, there are two swimming pools, a Jacuzzi, and a tennis court. For those wishing to travel around the area by bike, a rental service is offered. After exercising, luxuriate with the soothing comforts of L'Olivier Spa.

The hotel is located amid the first and authentic marina of Cap Corse, and it is also famous for being the birthplace of Paul Valéry's family.

Open from late March to mid-November.

content.title: Calvi Citadel, the majestic beauty of an icon

introduction.small: The famous Calvi Citadel rises proudly above the city, an iconic symbol of the historic and cultural heritage of Balagne.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Calvi Citadel, the majestic beauty of an icon

paragraphs.text:
Nestled on a rocky promontory northeast of the city, the Calvi Citadel offers a breath-taking panoramic 360-degree view. In this, Christopher Columbus' birthplace, the legendary city's sinuous steep streets take you into the heart of its history, its origins, and its culture.
During your walk, you can see the crumbling yet historic walls of Christopher Columbus' house, the Palace of the Governors, the chapel Saint-Antoine, and the renowned St. John the Baptist's Cathedral.
Calvi Citadel is a charming and lively place that regularly hosts cultural events such as art exhibitions and concerts.
Religious buildings also have the honour of hosting concerts of polyphonic songs, to the delight of locals and visitors. An idyllic stroll on one of the most beautiful sites of the island, abounding with pleasant charms.

Calvi Citadel

content.title: A Casa di Mà, the timeless harmony of aesthetics and elegance

introduction.small: Bathed in a singular alchemy comprised of escape and refinement, A Casa di Mà is a tastefully decorated 29-room hotel.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: A Casa di Mà, the timeless harmony of aesthetics and elegance

paragraphs.text:
An invitation to share a special moment in a warm atmosphere, lounging around the pool, reading a book in the shade on the terrace overlooking the Bay of Calvi, or pampering yourself in the massage room, where the best professionals in the region take turns to bring you quality care.

There is also a popular gastronomic restaurant, where fine cuisine is prepared with unique flavours, and two bars. Chef Romain Roland will let you discover genuine Corsican products with mouth-watering menus. Guests can enjoy these delicacies and refreshments on the terrace or in the contemporary dining rooms.

And if your stay includes professional obligations, A Casa di Mà features a meeting room with a capacity of six-30 people where you can work in confidence.

content.title: Corsican basketry, the art of weaving vegetation

introduction.small: Part of the island's cultural heritage, Annick Rony's basket works produce daily handicrafts from vegetation.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Corsican basketry, the art of weaving vegetation

paragraphs.text:
After a morning in Saleccia Park to admire the beauty of the seabed, take to the heights in the village of Calenzana to meet Annick Rony in the shade of olive trees.

Her desire to not let go of this ancient island tradition led her to apprentice with Jean-Luc, a famous shepherd from Lumio and Algaghjola. In her workshop, surrounded by the intoxicating smells of the maquis, her creations, made with branches of myrtle, olive, and reed, will astound.

Since 2002, this artisan basket maker has handled secateurs and pruning knives to manually work the raw materials into unique pieces. The beauty of these singular trays, wickerworks, and baskets charm and fascinate. At the end of the day, make a stop at the medieval town of Lama and discover the Campu Latinu, overlooking the Ostriconi valley, with a gorgeous sunset over crystal-clear waters.

content.title: Chez Tao, an irresistible and captivating piano bar

introduction.small: Perched on the heights of the citadel, Chez Tao is an iconic and much sought-after address for Calvaises nights.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Chez Tao, an irresistible and captivating piano bar

paragraphs.text:
In 1928, Tao Kerefoff, exiled along with Prince Felix Yusupov, Rasputin's famous assassin, arrived in northern Corsica. Captivated by the singular beauty of the small town of Calvi and desperately in love with Jeannette Maestracci, he decided to set-up here and so in 1935 created this, Corsica's first nightclub.

In this landmark 17th-century house, children, grandchildren, and great-grandchildren have maintained this magical, historical place, all the while respecting their ancestor's motto: 'Be happy today for tomorrow will be too late.'

Every summer, personalities, regulars, and tourists flock to party, dance, and sing.

During your trip to Calvi, you won't be able to resist the unique atmosphere that emanates from this address, which will also charm you with its view of the bay.

content.title: Aethos Corsica - U Palazzu Serenu: charm and authenticity

introduction.small: Now fully restored to its former glory, this 17th-century palace is located in Oletta.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Aethos Corsica - U Palazzu Serenu: charm and authenticity

paragraphs.text:
Overlooking the gorgeous Gulf of Saint-Florent and the arid Agriates Desert, the Florentine-style Aethos Corsica - U Palazzu Serenu is organized into nine spacious suites – the smallest of which is still a roomy 32m2 sqm! – decorated with noble and refined materials. The outdoor terrace offers wonderful views, and the 20-metre infinity pool is an open invitation for a swim. If you want to relax, take advantage of the excellent treatments available in the hotel's wellbeing suite. There's glorious artwork to enjoy, too, with signed pieces by internationally-acclaimed artists such as Anish Kapoor, Daniel Arsham, Paul de Pignol, Wendy Wischer, Udo Nöger, Manuel Merida, Yvan Rebyj, Kim Tschang Yeul and Conrad Marca-Relli on display in the bar, reception, lounge and rooms.
Last but not least, indulge in the very best of Italian cuisine during an intimate lunch or dinner at CECI, brought to you by Manuel André Fernandes and Italian chef Delfina Vincaretti.

For centuries, Oletta has also been called "Nebbio's gem", due to its rich soil, heritage and culture. Various activities are available to light up your stay, such as thematic strolls, a visit to the Sacred Art Museum, the Padula lake, pottery, craft workshops and the craft market of the San Francesco convent.

content.title: U Fragnu, olive oil in all its forms

introduction.small: A warm welcome awaits you in the village of Lunghignano at this atypical establishment of the Balanine region, which offers an invitation to discover and taste olive oils and handmade products.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: U Fragnu, olive oil in all its forms

paragraphs.text:
Though entirely renovated, the mill has managed to keep its authenticity, as the wheel is still pulled by Georges, the establishment's donkey. A true ambassador, Georges only works at harvest, two-and-a-half months every two years.

U Fragnu means "press", and it is a genuine piece of the Balagne cultural heritage as it showcases a millstone, three presses and a sedimentation tank. Its interior layout allows for the making of traditional olive oil, as well as tastings of various oils from different regions and producers. There's a short film that you can watch while you are tasting, too, that shows what goes on during pressing, which is useful as this often happens outside of the tourist season.
In addition to the olive farm, the owners have decided to open the rest of the property to visitors, including every nook and cranny of the magnificent press house.

With its sleek modern decor, the Résidence Dary combines the comfort of an apartment with the personalized services of a luxury hotel. Enjoy undisturbed quality services with views of the bay bathed in dappled light.

The property consists of six apartments, a heated outdoor swimming pool, a Jacuzzi, a concierge service, and private parking. If you wish, personalized services such as breakfast, laundry, shopping, house staff, hairstyling, etc. are available during your stay.

If you are tempted to elope, set out to explore Montemaggiore. This village was built on a promontory, overlooking the Fiume Secco lake. At the foot of Mount Grosso, is offers a large panorama over Calvi's gulf, the Revellata archipelago and the mountain ranges.

content.title: Raugi, quality craftsmanship from father to son since 1937

introduction.small: In Bastia, Raugi is a real institution. Young and old gather to enjoy delicious hand-made ice creams and dishes on or off the premises.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Raugi, quality craftsmanship from father to son since 1937

paragraphs.text:
In 1937, Alverado, Aladin, and Gina made ice creams and meandered about the town and neighbouring villages on their small motorcycle-truck to sell them.

In 1950, the three partners set up shop on Chanoine Colombani street. Since then, their successors have maintained this unique recipe and have continued to perpetuate their ancestor's 'savoir faire'. Concerned about the quality of their products, they test their painstakingly designed creations in a laboratory.

They offer their customers a palette of more than 100 flavours made with high quality raw materials to be discovered through ice creams, sorbets, desserts, and Yule logs. And if you are in the mood for something savoury, Raugi also makes delicious pizzas and salads. The company counts four addresses strategically spread around town, each boasting a different atmosphere.

content.title: The Pool Bar, luxury in discretion

introduction.small: Located within the three-hectare natural park of La Villa, overlooking the majestic Bay of Calvi, the Pool Bar offers a sophisticated atmosphere.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The Pool Bar, luxury in discretion

paragraphs.text:
Sip a glass of wine or a house cocktail while listening to a piano concerto comfortably seated in the sofas alongside the pool. Jean-Pierre Pinelli, the owner, an enthusiast of classical music, organises free musical events every summer, where voluntary donations made by spectators benefit charities.

If you feel peckish, the chef will arouse and satisfy your taste buds. And if you wish to prolong your stay, do not hesitate to reserve a table at La Table by La Villa, the hotel's gastronomic restaurant. Note that this idyllic address is only open from June 1st till September 15th.

Very close by, you can visit the Gulf of Girolata. Preserved inland, the hamlet is part of the town of Osani. You can only access it by sea, or walking a path starting from the Col de la Croix. Ferries are operated for boat trips.

A warm welcome is reserved for you in this idyllic setting with 29 rooms and two suites, with balcony or terrace, in a carefully selected variety of natural materials, offering views of the garden, river, or mountain, thus creating a unique place where the mineral and the vegetable are harmoniously combined. Smell the scents of the Mediterranean garden designed by landscape architect Pierre-Jean, relax on the terraces along the river, swim in the pool, or curl up in the plush armchairs in the living room library and flip through a book.
The town of Corte, commonly referred to as "Core di Corsica" (heart of Corsica) is located at the centre of the island, 68km from Bastia and 80km from Ajaccio. You can wander through alleyways filled with history, sip on a cool drink in the shade of a plane tree, visit a museum or simply gaze at the meandering cats.

content.title: Erbalunga, a picturesque fishing village

introduction.small: With its broken Genoese tower, picturesque alleys, archways, and its fishing port, the village of Erbalunga is a renowned tourist resort, full of charm and poetry.

Stop at the head of Cap Corse in this picturesque conservation area. The Brando Marina has inspired many island painters to immortalise its soul, welcoming you in a setting outside of time.

Enjoy the soothing environment of this enchanting place, in the village square or at the water's edge, on the shaded terraces of restaurants and cafes.

Satisfy your curiosity by strolling through the little shops. During the summer season, take the opportunity to attend cultural events such as 'Piano Nights of Erbalunga' in the open-air theatre.

If you are looking for sports activities, the town's professionals will indicate the best snorkelling sites, or arrange horseback riding, hiking, and even climbing. Finish your tour at Le Pirate gastronomic restaurant, where you will feast upon dishes prepared by a talented chef.

content.title: Le Clémenceau, cutlery creator

introduction.small: Since 1999, Pol Demongeot has been creating unique pieces of cutlery in Fort Mozzello, across from the Citadel of Calvi.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Le Clémenceau, cutlery creator

paragraphs.text:
After creating his first knife in 1984 at Jean-Pierre Ceccaldi's workshops in Zonza, Pol Demongeot joined Franck Thomas for ten years at Lotus cutlery, and then worked at the Lumio Ethnographic Centre of Metallurgical Research alongside Christian Moretti. A tamer of materials, Pol Demongeot displays his mastery of steel with his coal forge.

Make a stop in at the Le Clémenceau shop when tootling about to admire the creativity of its mineral and bronze collections and have a chat with Regis Bonnaffous, a big fan of steel and this exceptional craft. You may then proceed with your local exploration and buy some Lonzu, dried sausages or a slice of Sabiani cheese at the famous Annie Traiteur deli, located on Clemenceau street. paragraphs.text:
Located on the western coast of Cap Corse, a green-schist square tower looms over the Medieval town of Nonza, which gives onto a spread-out beach at the end of a small valley.

Emmanuel and his attentive team are delighted to receive you in this unique setting, which offers one of the most beautiful terraces of the whole island. Offering much more than a view, La Sassa is the trendy address on the Cap Corse. Personalities from the island and the mainland, both known and anonymous, come together in this lounge atmosphere for a drink, or to taste the culinary specialties developed by the chef. You will be spoiled for choice between the tapas, salads, pizzas and grilled meats, and fish cooked over a wood fire. And in the evening, while watching the sunset bathe the tower and the valley, you can bust a move to the pulsing rhythms mixed by the resident DJ.

content.title: Morosaglia, the Corsican soul

introduction.small: Morosaglia, the birthplace of Corsican patriotism, nestles in the hills 800 metres above sea level.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Morosaglia, the Corsican soul

paragraphs.text:
In this village of old slate houses roofed with tiles, where Roman and Baroque edifices flourish, the great father figure of the island, Pascal Paoli (1753-1893) was born.

This twice-exiled head of the independent Corsican nation and figure of the enlightenment found very little benefit from the exceptional panorama offered by this site, which is now crossed by highway D71. Switchbacks lined with chestnut and oak trees join the Col de Prado and Porta to reveal a tough, proud, and beautiful universe with still-untouched landscapes, crossed by rivers that ring out the words of the fatherland's patriarch: "All worthy Corsicans are animated by the most beautiful fire, the most intrepid courage, and the most ardent zeal for freedom."

Discover the Pascal Paoli regional museum, set up in his birthplace of Morosaglia. The main area gathers artefacts and souvenirs. The visit ends with a tour of the funeral chapel, where Saint Pancras' ashes and tombstone are stored.

And if you want to explore further, discover the small and cool microregion of Caccia and its green Asco Valley.

Not only is the area bursting with lush vegetation, there are also multiple activities to enjoy, like trekking or swimming in the rivers' soft waters to gaze at the water animals.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Casanera, beauty Made in Maquis

paragraphs.text:
For over three generations, the Ceccaldi family have established a valuable herbarium of plants from the maquis. Raised on her grandmother and great-grandmother's anecdotes, Marie Ceccaldi praises the secret treasures of mother nature. A transmission of knowledge brought about with each blade of grass and flower petal. She searched for and tested the best fragrances to recreate the nectar of this particular flora, encapsulated in exceptional cosmetics and perfumes.

In 2010, Marie Ceccaldi developed a luxurious range of facials and body treatments. Ethically prepared, these handpicked plant-based cosmetic products respect ancestral know-how and the methodical distillation of essential oils produced in Balagne.

Explore this world of fragrances with creams, candles, perfumed water, and soaps. This sophisticated range of products may also be found in the sumptuous La Signoria Spa in Calvi.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Atelier Julien Truchon, the art of shaping the earth

After a potter's diploma from Saint-Amand-en-Puisaye (Burgundy) awarding a rigorous and intensive training, Julien Truchon continued his vocation and his trade, learning from recognised professionals. He then perfected his art with Japanese potters from Bizen, outside Okayama. With orders from regional, national, and internationally renowned restaurants, he now applies himself to designing dishes.

During your visit, discover a workshop with a long history and a showroom combining unique items, such as pots, bowls, plates, vases and incense burners, while trading talk with the master of the house about his expertise and inspirations. A visit placed under the sign of curiosity.

content.title: Discovering the GR20

introduction.small: The GR20 is the place for trekkers and hikers. Its reputation goes well beyond the borders of Corsica, and its northern section is deemed harder than that of its southern neighbour.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Discovering the GR20

paragraphs.text:
From Vizzavona to Asco, your physical condition will be put to the test and for that you must prepare yourself well before you venture out to avoid any inconvenience or possibly complicated situation.

Once you are well equipped to cross the highest mountain passes, your journey takes you past glacial lakes before crossing the famous and aptly named "cirque de la Solitude" (cirque of Loneliness).

The GR20 is an authentic route that crosses all of Corsica on 200 kilometres, from the northwest to the southeast, along the coastline. Mountains and sea, lakes and peaks, they all come up at some point on the way. A variety of trails, stays and hikes, training sessions and intensive sporting preparations are all available, with or without local professionals to guide you. It is possible to build your activity list depending on your capabilities and activities of choice, and therefore discover on foot local fauna and flora in all their richness.

content.title: Domaine Pieretti, a family wine tradition

introduction.small: Built in 1994 by the sea at the northern end of the village of Santa Severa, the Domaine Pieretti vineyard offers visitors tastings and direct sales of its different vintages.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Domaine Pieretti, a family wine tradition

paragraphs.text:
Surrounded by shrubland and sea, the Domaine Pieretti vineyards stretch across the hills as far as the eye can see. The winery has been modernised with the aim of making its processes as sustainable as possible, and now not only has a pneumatic press and thermoregulated stainless steel tanks, but also takes pride in harvesting all its grapes by hand. What's more, the bracing sea breeze protects the vines from a number of diseases and keeps them wonderfully healthy, resulting in less treatment, and fewer CO2-emitting tractor journeys.
Domaine Pieretti, whose wines are recognised regionally and nationally, produces about 45,000 bottles a year of crus including Muscat de Cap Corse AOP, Vin de Pays de l'Île de Beauté, and Corse Coteaux du Cap Corse AOP. After your tasting, you can walk into the village and go to the Tower of Seneca. Located west of the Luri valley towards Pinu and clinging to rocks, this building constructed by the Dei Moti family during the second half of the 16th century was named after the famous Roman philosopher-because he was sentenced to exile there by Emperor Claudius for the crime of adultery.

Take the opportunity to chat with the affable owners Fernand Sker, who also oversees the fishing, and with his wife, Marie-Thé.

After this gourmet break, walk around the marina, where you will discover fishermen's houses covered in flowers. Then gain some height and enjoy the views over the steep hilly landscape of Capo Bianco, north of Centuri, its green-tinted rocks reflected in the deep waters. Located northwest of Cap Corse, the town is bordered by the Mandrioni ridge on the east and on the north, as well as a skyline that goes from Bocca di Serra to Punta di Colombara.

After a stroll, enjoy a rest on the panoramic hotel terrace overlooking the port in this mansion of faded colours at the tip of Cap Corse.

Before diving into the water to admire the seabed, you can keep on the coastal footpath to discover the beauty of Saleccia Beach. At the end of the day, head back to the village of Saint-Florent, to stroll along the docks, wander around the narrow streets of the old neighbourhood leading to Sainte-Anne Church and the Piazza Posta: the square of the former post office is a kids delight, with its "frogs' fountain" and fresh spots in summer.

content.title: La Villa Calvi, an exceptional location

With its exceptional rooms and suites, its Michelin-starred restaurant, its many activities (pool tables, pools, spa…), La Villa Calvi offers its guests a haven of peace and a sublime blend of luxury and refinement.

For 20 years, the owners have been striving to make La Villa Calvi the place to stay in Balagne.

Admire the works of artists invited to exhibit in this universe of meticulous design, and wander the gardens listening to the melodies of concerts given to benefit charities.

This idyllic address located in "Corsica's garden" displays a thousand and one flavours. Balagne is actually situated halfway between the mountain and the sea, and filled with olive, fig, apple and palm orchards. It is scattered with beautiful and high perched villages, replete with narrow streets and typical houses like in Sant'Antonino, Spéloncato, Pigna, Lumio, Belgodère, as well as magnificent churches in Corbara and Aregno.

content.title: Lake Nino, paradise lost

introduction.small: On the route of the mythical GR20, Lake Nino, located in the mountains, offers an invigorating walking getaway.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Lake Nino, paradise lost

paragraphs.text:
Lake Nino, the second largest lake in Corsica, has an exceptional setting for enjoying a hike or horse-riding experience.

Starting near Vergio Pass, not far from the forest house of Popaggia, take the marked trail to climb toward the Valdoniello forest until reaching the Bocca a Stazzona. After two-and-a-half hours walking, you will discover the vastness of Lake Nino and its pozzines (water wells, where it is forbidden to tread) where wild horses graze. Pass under the Capu a u Tozzu (viewpoint) to then join the Col de Saint-Pierre. Back on the marked path, make your way to the starting point.

At about 14 km and six hours of walking, this tour requires good physical condition and the preparation of a small backpack that includes a first-aid kit.

content.title: CLIMATE AND WEATHER IN Bastia
content.introduction: Bastia and northern Corsica enjoys a Mediterranean climate. Summers (June to September) are hot and dry, while winters are especially mild (only 5 days with freezing temperatures each year in northern Corsica, on average). Winds can be strong at times and rainfall rather heavy (particularly from September to December). But Corsica is also well known for its exceptional sunshine!

Getting from the airport to Bastia and back:
  • By car
    • Accessible via the N193 road.
    • Car parks: P1 (Commercial), P2 (Long Stay) and P4 (Long Stay): 2 EUR for 15-30 minutes (first 15 minutes are free), 2.50 EUR for 30-45 minutes, 3 EUR for 45 minutes-1 hour. Every subsequent 15 minutes costs 0.10 EUR to a maximum 12 hours of parking (then 14 EUR for 24 hours for P1 and 10 EUR for 24 hours for P2 and P4).
    • Several car rental companies have counters at the airport.
  • By bus
    • Autobus Bastiais operates shuttle bus services between the airport and the city centre (departing from Terminus Bastia train station). Travel time is about 25 minutes and the one-way fare is EUR 9.
  • Taxi
    • Taxis are available at the ranks outside the Arrivals hall. The daytime fare to the city centre is about EUR 48. Between 7 p.m. and 7 a.m., expect a night fare of around EUR 66.
  • Services: bars and restaurants, newsstand, and free Internet access (Wi-Fi) available in the airport.
  • Telephone: +33 (0)4 95 54 54 54
  • Website: bastia.aeroport.fr/en/



Calvi Sainte-Catherine Airport

The Calvi Sainte-Catherine Airport is located about 7km (4 miles) south-east of the city centre.
  • One terminal

Getting from the airport to Calvi and back
  • By car
    • Accessible via the N197, then the D81 roads (Route de l'Aéroport). Travel time to the city centre is about 8 minutes.
    • A paid parking area with 200 spaces is available (First 15 minutes of parking are free, then EUR 1.00 for 15 to 30 minutes, EUR 1.10 for 30 to 45 minutes, EUR 1.20 for 1 hour and EUR 6.00 for 24 hours).
    • Several car rental companies have counters at the airport.
  • By taxi
    • A taxi rank is located outside the Arrivals hall. The fare to the city centre is about EUR 20.
  • Services: bars, vending machines, newsstand, and free Internet access (Wi-Fi) available in the airport.
  • Telephone: +33 (0)4 95 65 88 88
  • Website: http://calvi.aeroport.fr/en/

localCalendar.title: FESTIVALS, HOLIDAYS AND OTHER ANNUAL EVENTS IN Bastia
localCalendar.description: There are a number of festivals, holidays and other events celebrated in northern Corsica each year. The main ones are listed below.

events.title: March or April : Easter Monday (national holiday)
May 1: Labour Day (national holiday)
events.description: On May 1<sup>st</sup>, it is customary to offer a sprig of lily-of-the-valley to close ones. Many vendors occupy the pavement on that occasion!

events.title: May 8: Victory Day (national holiday)
events.description: Commemorates the Allied victory in Europe that ended World War II on this day in 1945. Various ceremonies are held around town.

events.title: June 21: Fête de la Musique (celebrated nationwide)
events.description: Also celebrated internationally as World Music Day, for this festival many free concerts featuring all types of music are held in the streets and at various venues around Corsica.

events.title: July–September: Bastia in Festa (local event)
events.description: Over this 90-day period, Bastia organizes 90 concerts, stage shows, exhibitions and other events. Unmissable!

events.title: July 14: Bastille Day (national holiday)
events.description: This holiday celebrates the storming of the Bastille prison in 1789, the key event marking the beginning of the French Revolution. It plays as a symbol of the end of the privileges enjoyed by the clergy and the aristocracy. Festivities in northern Corsica include concerts and dance parties. At nightfall, dazzling fireworks displays light up the skies over many Corsican towns and villages.

events.title: August 15: Assumption Day (national holiday)
events.description: This celebration, still very popular in Corsica, is marked by the faithful with several religious ceremonies and processions through the streets.

events.title: Third weekend in September: European Heritage Days (celebrated nationwide)
events.description: The aim of the European Heritage Days is to open up numerous sites and monuments, many of which are normally closed to the public, such as castles and private collections. A great opportunity for a lovely stroll through the city to admire architectural treasures!

events.title: November 11: Remembrance Day (national holiday)
events.description: On this day, French citizens gather at war memorials to commemorate the signing of the 1918 Armistice officially bringing an end to the First World War.

events.title: December 31: New Year's Eve (national event)
events.description: On the night of December 31<sup>st</sup>, the atmosphere is particularly festive on the streets of Bastia, with families and friends celebrating the new year.

goodToKnow.tips:
Tipping
In Northern Corsica like elsewhere in France, a service charge is always included in the bill. If you are particularly pleased with the service, you may certainly leave a few extra euros on the table. But this additional tip is neither expected nor necessary.
